description: From commit +‎ -ee, or else revival of Anglo-Norman commite, past participle of commettre (“to commit”), from Latin committere, from con- (“with”) + mittere (“to send”).  The OED3 prefers the first etymology.

entries.meaning: A body of one or more persons convened for the accomplishment of some specific purpose, typically with formal protocols.
examples: My uncle is on the committee.

entries.meaning: (archaic) A guardian; someone in charge of another person deemed to be unable to look after themself.
